title: What time is the Brexit vote tomorrow?
text:
We’re getting down to the wire… (Picture: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire

Less than two weeks before the UK is due to leave the EU, MPs will vote on Prime Minister Boris Johnson‘s new Brexit deal.

The deal has been agreed upon by EU leaders so tomorrow, 19 October, Johnson will face the House of Commons in an effort to get his deal passed before the UK is due to leave the EU at 11pm on 31 October.

MPs will have had two days to consider their stance on the Brexit deal before they cast their ballot.

What time is the Brexit vote tomorrow?

While we don’t know exactly what time tomorrow’s Brexit vote will be, according to Parliament’s website, MPs will sit from 9:30am tomorrow, when the Prime Minister will give a statement.

If previous Brexit debates are anything to go by, we can expect a dramatic day in the House of Commons on what is being called Super Saturday.

Tomorrow will mark the first Saturday this century during which MPs have sat in the House of Commons.

Johnson has said there is a ‘very good case’ for MPs to vote in favour of his deal, however there is a significant opposition for him to overcome, with the DUP having rejected the deal.

SNP parliamentary leader Ian Blackford has said the opposition parties need to ‘quit dithering, back our amendment, and finally act to bring this appalling Tory government down and stop Brexit’.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has also said in no uncertain terms: ‘As it stands we cannot support this deal.’

Meanwhile, the Prime Minister has said: ‘I am very confident that when my colleagues in Parliament study this agreement that they will want to vote for it on Saturday and in succeeding days.’

The terms of this new Brexit deal include the scrapping of the contentious Northern Irish Backstop

Advertisement

Advertisement

If the deal passes, Northern Ireland will be in the UK customs territory ‘forever’ and will benefit from any free trade deals the UK strikes.

There will also be no hard border between the two Irelands.

Johnson’s new deal has also scrapped the UK’s commitment to a ‘single customs territory’, confirming the need for checks at the border, which ITV’s Joel Hills says will make some UK/EU trade more expensive.

Political Declaration is out. Much of it is unchanged but gone is commitment to “a trading relationship on goods that is as close as possible”. Instead a “free trade agreement”. This matters. Higher trade barriers = greater economic cost. pic.twitter.com/C3D2fbMg2T — Joel Hills (@ITVJoel) October 17, 2019
